conclusion: Determine the propagation speed of light in water given the vertex angle α of the inverted cone and the speed of light in vacuum C.
The problem describes an inverted cone where the vertex angle is α.
The angle between the two lines forming the cone's sides is α.
The speed of light in a medium is related to the speed of light in vacuum by the refractive index n of the medium.
The relationship is given by v = C/n where v is the speed of light in the medium.
The refractive index n can be related to the angle α using Snell's Law and the geometry of the cone.
For an inverted cone with vertex angle α, the refractive index n is given by n = sin(α/2) / sin((π - α)/2).
Simplifying the argument of the sine function: n = sin(α/2) / cos(α/2) = tan(α/2).
Substitute n = tan(α/2) into the speed equation: v = C / tan(α/2).
The propagation speed of light in water is C / tan(α/2).
